note.p: This is a fragment of 'Li dai fa bao ji' (See Or.8210/S.516/R.1) containing the biographies of the fifth and sixth Patriarchs of the Tang dynasty [i.e. Hongren and Huineng]. The chronicle traces the history of Buddhism in China from AD 60-774. Its contents and its significance as evidence for a Sichuan branch of Chan which honoured four patriarchs - Zhishen (609-701) to Wuzhu (714-74) - are examined in278-349(summarized in82). Yanagida 1983, an English translation of the introduction to his edition of P.2125, summarizes the history, literary features, and teachings of the chronicle and supplies a bibliography. Additional mss. segments include a nearly complete text in S.516/R.1, and partial texts on Or.8210/S.1611, Or.8210/S.5916, P.3717, and P.3727. Adamek is preparing a forthcoming English translation.
Variant version of 'Heze heshang wenda za zhengyi' (Miscellaneous Dialogues of the Venerable of Heze) which survives in P.3047 (see) and the Ishii ms. (seevol. 3). It is by Shenhui.
